profileText: (Grandson of Edward James Gay [1816-1889]), a Senator from Louisiana; born on Union Plantation, Iberville Parish, La., May 5, 1878; attended Pantops Academy, Charlottesville, Va., the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School, and Princeton University; engaged in sugar production and the cultivation of various agricultural products; member, State house of representatives 1904-1918; elected on November 5, 1918, as a Democrat to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Robert F. Broussard and served from November 6, 1918, to March 3, 1921; declined to be a candidate for reelection in 1920; chairman, Committee on Coast and Insular Survey (Sixty-fifth Congress); president of a manufacturing company and of the Lake Long Drainage District, Iberville Parish; died in New Orleans, La., December 1, 1952; interment in Metairie Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the Gay family papers, 1806-1925. 100,000 items. Includes senatorial correspondence and papers, chiefly correspondence with servicemen, constituent correspondence, legislative correspondence, and subject files on League of Nations, military discharge, passports, post office, postal commission, railroads, suffrage, sugar, military academies, and other topics. Also includes Edward J. Gay Planting and Manufacturing Company records (1893-1911).

recordLocation.name: Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections

researchRecord.name: Campaign flyer with biographical sketch and platform (1918) in Melrose collection, 1700s-1948.
